riceblast 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Univariate blast detection framework
    • Exploring Field 1 data

    Assess test set observations against estimated anomalous thresholds

    test_extremes_uni.Rd

    Extends the analysis from model_extremes_uni by generating forecasts and evaluating model residuals and forecast errors relative to the estimated lower extreme threshold. This helps to assess whether future values fall within the expected range or cross the lower extreme boundary. The function allows the inclusion of new test data, which is combined with the training (typical) data to create a complete dataset for residual and forecast error analysis.

    test_extremes_uni(analysis_result, test_data, h = 1000)

    Arguments

    analysis_result

    A list object returned by model_extremes_uni, containing the fitted model, lower limit, and related metadata.

    test_data

    A tsibble or data frame containing the test/forecast period data. This will be combined with the typical_data from model_extremes_uni to form the full dataset used for error analysis.

    h

    Integer. The forecast horizon, i.e., the number of future observations to predict. Default is 1000.

    Value

    A list containing:

    model

    The fitted model object from model_extremes_uni.

    forecast

    A fable forecast object containing mean forecasts and intervals.

    all_errors

    A tsibble containing both fitted residuals and forecast errors.

    lower_limit

    The estimated lower extreme threshold (from the model analysis).

    full_data

    The combined dataset consisting of typical_data and test_data.

    response

    The response variable name as a character string.

    Details

    The function performs two main tasks:

    • Generates forecasts (h steps ahead) using the fitted model.

    • Combines fitted residuals (from the training window) and forecast errors (from the forecasted window) into a unified time series object for downstream analysis and visualization.

    Forecast errors are computed as the difference between the observed response variable and the forecast mean. Both fitted and forecast errors are combined with labels for easy comparison and plotting.

    Examples

    
# Create a sample daily time series dataset
data <- tsibble::tsibble(
  date = seq.Date(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2020-12-31"), by = "day"),
  value = c(rnorm(300),rnorm(66, -3)),
  index = date
)

result <- model_extremes_uni(
  full_data = data,
  time_col = date,
  typical_start = "2020-01-01",
  typical_end = "2020-08-30",
  response = value,
  thr_prob_fit = 0.1,
  t_method = "boxplot"
)
#> # A tsibble: 243 x 2 [1D]
#>    date        value
#>    <date>      <dbl>
#>  1 2020-01-01 -1.64 
#>  2 2020-01-02  0.508
#>  3 2020-01-03  1.75 
#>  4 2020-01-04  0.592
#>  5 2020-01-05  1.02 
#>  6 2020-01-06  0.122
#>  7 2020-01-07 -1.08 
#>  8 2020-01-08 -1.14 
#>  9 2020-01-09 -0.530
#> 10 2020-01-10 -0.681
#> # ℹ 233 more rows

test_data <- data |>
  dplyr::filter(date > as.Date("2020-06-30")) |>
  dplyr::select(date, value) |>
  tsibble::as_tsibble(index = date)

test_result <- riceblast::test_extremes_uni(result,test_data = test_data,  h = 200)

test_result
#> $model
#> # A mable: 1 x 1
#>   `fable::ARIMA(value)`
